title: Man's sash
content:
accession_no_csv: 2017-00061

  Image:

  title_text: Man\u0027s sash

  preference: main

  creation_date: Late 19th - early 20th century

  creation_place_original_location: Sumatra (Indonesia)

  inscriptions:

  shape: rectangular

  materials_name: silk (textile) metal thread

  techniques_name: sewing (needleworking technique) embroidering

  object_colour: multicolored

  physical_appearance: This is a long sash. The sash is blue
 with the ends featuring embroidery work comprised of brightly-coloured
 geometric patterns. The ends of the panels are bordered by stitched triangles. There are several tears in the middle of the sash.

  subject_terms_1: geometric motifs ceremonial costume embroidery (visual works) folk costume

  subject_terms_2: Motifs Ethnic costume Embroidery Sashes (Clothing)

  subject_terms_3: Chinese costumes

  sgcool_label_text: The form of this sash is similar to Chinese men’s sashes.  Both ends of the sash are embroidered in drawn work technique.  The embroidery panels comprise brightly-coloured
 geometric patterns.  They are segmented by flattened and couched metallic thread work.  The pointed end of the panels are bordered by triangles in darning stitches.  The style of this drawn work is typical of West Sumatran examples
 which features angular animal motifs as well.  Gold bobbin lace and the sawtooth motif worked in a variant of buttonhole stitch bind the edges of the sash.  Given its labour intensive production and choice of silk
 this sash may have been worn as part of a ceremony
 such as a wedding.

metadata.physical_appearance: This is a long sash. The sash is blue, with the ends featuring embroidery work comprised of brightly-coloured, geometric patterns. The ends of the panels are bordered by stitched triangles. There are several tears in the middle of the sash.
metadata.subject_terms_1: geometric motifs ceremonial costume embroidery (visual works) folk costume
metadata.sgcool_label_text: The form of this sash is similar to Chinese men’s sashes.  Both ends of the sash are embroidered in drawn work technique.  The embroidery panels comprise brightly-coloured, geometric patterns.  They are segmented by flattened and couched metallic thread work.  The pointed end of the panels are bordered by triangles in darning stitches.  The style of this drawn work is typical of West Sumatran examples, which features angular animal motifs as well.  Gold bobbin lace and the sawtooth motif worked in a variant of buttonhole stitch bind the edges of the sash.  Given its labour intensive production and choice of silk, this sash may have been worn as part of a ceremony, such as a wedding.
